results.title: ‘Little Shop of Horrors’ at 40: The Plant That Conquered the World
results.abstract: Members of the cast and creative team from the original production, as well as the current Off Broadway revival, look back on how the show came together and discuss its enduring influence.

multimedia.caption: The cast and creative team of the original production of “Little Shop of Horrors.” In the front at center are Howard Ashman, left, wearing plaid, and Alan Menken, lying on the floor.
The cast and creative team of the original production of “Little Shop of Horrors.” In the front at center are Howard Ashman, left, wearing plaid, and Alan Menken, lying on the floor.
The cast and creative team of the original production of “Little Shop of Horrors.” In the front at center are Howard Ashman, left, wearing plaid, and Alan Menken, lying on the floor.

results.title: Cannes Film Festival 2022: Politics Mixed With Moments of Grace
results.abstract: “Top Gun: Maverick,” “Tchaikovsky’s Wife” and other movies each get polemical in their own way. But there are scenes of lyrical beauty, as in “Scarlet.”

multimedia.caption: Tom Cruise in the new sequel to his 1986 blockbuster, “Top Gun.”
Tom Cruise in the new sequel to his 1986 blockbuster, “Top Gun.”
Tom Cruise in the new sequel to his 1986 blockbuster, “Top Gun.”

results.title: ‘I Want to Live in That Room’: Designers on Their Broadway Sets
results.abstract: Live theater summons energy no digital performance can match. Set designers for five of this season’s plays explain how they built eye-catching environments that crackle with it.
results.byline: By Laura Collins-Hughes and Vincent Tullo

multimedia.caption: Christine Jones’s wondrous set design for “Birthday Candles,” our critic Maya Phillips wrote in her review, manages to convey eloquent whimsy — births, deaths, love, despair, whole constellations of human feelings and thoughts.

Christine Jones’s wondrous set design for “Birthday Candles,” our critic Maya Phillips wrote in her review, manages to convey eloquent whimsy — births, deaths, love, despair, whole constellations of human feelings and thoughts.

results.title: David Fincher Tries Animation in ‘Love, Death + Robots’
results.abstract: The director made his first animated short for the new season of this Netflix anthology. “It was an incredibly freeing, eye-opening, mind-expanding way to interface with a story,” he said.

multimedia.caption: “Bad Travelling,” part of the new season of “Love, Death + Robots,” on Netflix, was David Fincher’s first animated short.
“Bad Travelling,” part of the new season of “Love, Death + Robots,” on Netflix, was David Fincher’s first animated short.
“Bad Travelling,” part of the new season of “Love, Death + Robots,” on Netflix, was David Fincher’s first animated short.

results.title: Samora Pinderhughes Explored Incarceration in Song. The Result Is ‘Grief.’
results.abstract: The vocalist, pianist and composer interviewed roughly 100 people of color who had experienced “structural violence” and created the Healing Project, a three-part interdisciplinary work.

multimedia.caption: Samora Pinderhughes has emerged as one of the most affecting singer-songwriters today.
multimedia.copyright: Geoffrey Haggray for The New York Times

results.title: With Her First Opera, Rhiannon Giddens Returns to Her Roots
results.abstract: “Omar,” composed by Giddens and Michael Abels, and based on the life a Muslim scholar sold into slavery, premieres at the Spoleto Festival USA.

multimedia.caption: Rhiannon Giddens’s music follows what she calls her mission: “uncovering and highlighting parts of our history that have been suppressed to tell a false narrative that is tearing us apart.”
multimedia.copyright: Elizabeth Bick for The New York Times

results.title: At Cannes, Vincent Lindon Still Can’t Believe He’s Jury President
results.abstract: As the star of a Palme d’Or winner, he’s seen how the award can change lives, so he takes his duties seriously.

multimedia.caption: Vincent Lindon said he expected the experience of serving as jury president would change him: “My own cinema world won’t be the same.”
Vincent Lindon said he expected the experience of serving as jury president would change him: “My own cinema world won’t be the same.”

results.title: Dancing to ‘Billie Jean’ Led Him to ‘MJ.’ Now He’s a Tony Contender.
results.abstract: Just five years after he performed as Michael Jackson at a high school talent show, Myles Frost is making his debut in a Broadway musical about the King of Pop.

multimedia.copyright: Donavon Smallwood for The New York Times

results.title: At the Shed, Frieze II Takes Off
results.abstract: The world’s largest, most luxurious and hard-to-get-to art fair embraces its new manageable size and accessible location. Thank the art fair gods.

results.title: The Bolero Is Timeless. Miguel Zenón Is Giving It a Jazzy Tinge.
results.abstract: The saxophonist and his longtime collaborator Luis Perdomo reimagined some of their favorite Latin American ballads for an album that made deep connections during the pandemic.

multimedia.caption: “If I wanted to play something slow, instead of playing standards from the Great American Songbook, I’d rather go into my world, you know?” Miguel Zenón said.
multimedia.copyright: Steven Molina Contreras for The New York Times

results.title: Bruce Mau: A Designer Puts Life on the Drawing Boards
results.abstract: A new film about the celebrated graphic designer follows his career as the scale of his projects goes from small to extra large to global.

multimedia.caption: Bruce Mau is the subject of a documentary and career biography, from the designed page to the designed earth.

results.title: ‘Downton Abbey: A New Era’ Review: Gilded, Aged
results.abstract: The latest entry in the “Downton Abbey” franchise is amiable enough — though despite its subtitle, it rests most of its extravagant weight on cozy familiarity.

results.title: Lorraine Hansberry Statue to Be Unveiled in Times Square
results.abstract: A life-size likeness of the pioneering playwright will be unveiled in June as part of a new initiative to honor her legacy.

results.title: Demolition for Jail Can Go Forward, Judge Rules in a Suit Brought by Artists
results.abstract: Two artists, whose works are at risk of being moved and demolished, are seeking an injunction against the city construction, citing the Visual Artists Rights Act.

multimedia.caption: Kit-Yin Snyder’s “Seven Columns of the Temple of Wisdom,” at the Manhattan Detention Complex on White Street. The jail is being razed to make way for a new one. Her work may be moved to a facility at Rikers.

results.title: How Los Angeles Has Changed (in a Good Way)
results.abstract: The city has a lot more to offer than the obvious, with new genre-bending restaurants and bars, and happenings galore. Its comeback story is well underway.

results.title: Basquiat Tops Phillips Contemporary Sale at $85 Million
results.abstract: “Basquiat is not just an artist; for a lot of the people out there, he’s a religion,” one dealer said. But Wednesday there were plenty of newcomers to watch.

multimedia.caption: Jean-Michel Basquiat’s “Untitled,” in acrylic and spray paint on canvas, from 1982, sold for $85 million on Wednesday night at Phillips. The estimate was around $70 million.

results.title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Upload’ and More
results.abstract: I’m the assistant film editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching and listening to.

results.title: Nuri Bilge Ceylan’s Masterpiece of Existential Angst
results.abstract: His moody 2004 film, ‘Distant,’ about an unemployed factory worker in Istanbul, has been revived for a short run at Film Forum in Manhattan.
